narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: ER&M 300, as a required course for majors, engages many seminal texts related to the history of the field of ethnic studies, along with critical studies methodologies. While many of the themes and readings overlapped with other classes, it was helpful to have this space shared with other ER&M majors who think critically about the challenges and tensions that exist within ethnic studies.
This class deepened my understanding of Ethnic Studies as a discipline and was an opportunity for deep engagement and growth along with other ER&M majors

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Very manageable workload, no major assignments except the final project and weekly reading responses, provides a space to create community within the ER&M major, invites some terrific guest speakers
Weaknesses: The syllabus could be tweaked to include more methods-based readings and prepare juniors for the senior project. There should be more of an orientation towards Black and Indigenous scholarship rather than multicultural, identify-affirming content.

Strengths: builds a sense of cohort among ER&M majors, Dr. Habchi was a really thoughtful professor and engaged deeply with our comments and reading responses

Weaknesses: Would have appreciated more of an emphasis on methodology/skills and framework for application in other ER&M projects

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Great to build community across the major.

Yes, because it is required for majors, but be prepared for some of the content to feel repetitive/redundant, especially if you've taken other ER&M classes. The access to guest speakers is one of the exciting and unique aspects of this course.
